name: Reina the Grifter - Twenty Side Store Championship 1st Place
Neural Strike v3.1
NBN - Primetime Blitz
description:
Fast Advance. Looking for feedback on the number and selection of Ice. Other feedback is of course also welcomed.

I also changed my Agenda layout from 12 to 11 and now I'm at 43 cards and can't decide what to add or just change my Agendas back,

name: Gamers Den 2014 Store Champion 1st Place Deck
description:
This deck won the 2014 Store Championships in Corpus Christi, Texas on the 22nd at the Gamers Den.

Round 1: (4-0) Played against HBFA and Andromeda. Won both matches.

Round 2: (4-0) Played against Jinteki and Kate. Won both matches.

Round 3: (2-2) Played against NBN and Gabriel. Lost to NBN due to so many closed accounts but killed Gabe first turn.

Round 4: (2-2) Played against Weyland and Kit. Lost to Kit because he played 2 R&D Interface and found 3 agendas stuck to each other worth 6 points and already had 2. I had the combo ready to win on my turn if he had just stolen 1 or 2 agendas. Reina killed Weyland really good with Knight/Clone Chip with Medium going.

Overall the decks finished with 12 points and earned first place.

If anyone has a question let me know!

description: The original creator of the idea for this deck is Martin Parsley [Building A Better World - Supermodernism v.2 (Plugged In Winner, San Mateo) ]. I only changed one Agenda. Huge thanks for this man and his brain!

name: Ser Gabriel vHJ1.0
description: My version of Crimsonwraiths excellent Ser Gabriel deck. Looking over the cards I felt this deck benefited greatly from e3 Feedback implants. With e3 Knight becomes even better, it breaks an archer for 5c(!), an Ichi 2.0 for 4c, Hadrians wall for 3c, etc. This also mitigates peacocks drawback for cheaper code gates (enigma, datapike, etc) while giving you a huge boost against Heimdall 1.0, Ichi 1.0, Eli, etc. With the ability to get into HQ easier with Knight I dropped an inside job (which doesn't work well with account siphon even if it does with Gabes ability) and with the INF saved from Yog (I truly prefer boostable breakers over Yog without Sucker tokens) and Indexing I added a Levy and a quality time. The draw from quality time and draw/ reset from Levy against Jinteki or high ICE decks aggressively trashing ICE with Knights on it is more valuable imo. I need to do some testing by nest saturday...I REALLY want to play this deck at the store championship!

Any comments would help.

name: 1.3.2.5.2 RP Refinery
description: So this is my upgraded version of a Dew Refinery deck. Money tends to not be a problem, but Cassia was an occasional hindrance. So, I took out one Jackson Howard (he was coming up more than I really needed him) and added in one Izzy McGuire. She is really handy when the one copy comes out. Otherwise one scoring server tends to be enough, with the rest of the ice concentrated on centrals and sprinkled over remotes. Great fun to play.

name: Boardroom Blitz (v1.0)
description:
After running into some trouble against NBN FA with my Andy deck, I decided to brew one of my own and try it out. I saw a couple of lists that used Profiteering, and it had a lot of appeal, since I wanted to run a higher econ aggressive version with 3x Biotic Labor and 3x SanSan City Grid. With Profiteering, I hopefully don't need Pop-Up Window or Subliminal Messaging. It's definitely possible to take too much bad pub and enable R&D lock, but used carefully I find it gives me a very helpful infusion of cash to rez the next SanSan / use the next Biotic Labor. The right answer seems to usually be to take 10c and 2 BP, not the full 15/3.

I also originally had 3x Anonymous Tip instead of Jackson, but after playing a friend's NBN FA with 3x Biotic and 3x Jackson, I concluded that the flexibility of Jackson to recur Biotics and SanSans would be worth it, especially in a 40-card deck. Running 40 cards instead of 44 increases the odds of seeing one or more of any 3-of in the first 10 cards (hand + 5 turns) by 4.5%, which is pretty significant to me. It's also why I'm not playing 2-ofs in my economy or FA cards.

When NAPD Contract comes out, I'll be revising this.

name: Clickety-click v1.0    (Rhur Valley + Strongbox)
description:
A deck built around the Rhur Valley + Strongbox combo. I tried making a Replicating Perfection list first, and a Stronger Together after, but went for Engineering the Future in the end, for two reasons: Bioroids and better economy. If you can't waste clicks to break through them, Bioroids become very very good for their cost.

Haas-Archology AI and GRNDL Refinery can be used to lure the runner and have him waste credits, and if he doesn't "fall" for it, you either get extra credits or extra clicks, so no loss anyway.

Scoring a 5/3 should be manageable and I like the idea of Project Wotan empowering the ICE Wotan (can't break for clicks, and it becomes very expensive) so I picked that instead of Priority Requisition.

name: Whizzard 1
NBN Making News 1
Talk To My Attorney (v1.6)
description: Updated based on my preferences after playing in the FFG Store Championship. I missed Daily Casts and didn't like John Masanori. So, no more Hostage package. It's performed well in limited testing since the tourney. The third Lawyer Up and second Emergency Shutdown would be great to have, but there aren't any good cuts to make.

name: Chessrunner
description:
Quite a shaper styled anarch deck. Gotta build up a big rig to support all the different chess pieces and then start dropping the run events for some fun shenanigans. Would say this hasn't been playtested and may well not be original but heck, I thought it would be a fun idea. Running Xanadu/Ice Carver to back up Rook/Bishops across the board and tax the corp would be a nice turn around. WitRD is meant to work with the HQ interface and the manouverability of the deep red-ed caissas to cause the corp to feel trapped if an agenda pops up on top - or a nice asset too if you consider whizzard's ability plus scrubber. One thing it's probably lacking is a real econ and I'm wondering if I replace the Stimhacks for something less dangerous, despite them being a nice last minute hell-for-leather run.

Thoughts?

name: Tricky Rush v1.1
description:
Pretty traditional fast advance skeleton; operation econ, medium-high ice density, cheap to rez end the run subroutines, and compressed advancement actions. Trick of Light and advanceable ice/assets to score 3/2 agendas from hand on the cheap. In the meantime you can enjoy higher/variable strength ice walls and shadows. There are a lot of moving parts here so don't wait for Trick of Light to be in HQ to advance ice. Get the advancement counters on the ice/asset and then focus on finding your Trick/Agenda.

  • Ghost Branch: Serves as a Trick of Light battery with integrated insurance policy. Costs 0 to trigger on access so you can set-and-forget. Put it behind Matrix Analyzer (advance Ghost Branch mid-run) or Data Raven for more tags. Install+Advance+Advance in the open as a diversion. If they run it then they either spend the rest of their turn dropping tags or leave you free to Psychographics another 3/2. If they leave it you can Trick of Light later. Install+Advance+Advance on a rezzed SanSan City Grid while you search for your next agenda. The Runner MUST access it if they want to trash SanSan.

  • SanSan City Grid: Fast advance option and economic weapon rolled into one. Install and leave unrezzed behind 1-2 pieces of ice. If the runner leaves it then use it to fast advance score when you have the money and agenda. If they run and trash then you just took 5+ credits and a click on a run that can't get them points.

  • Psychographics: Hold onto these for when the runner gets reckless and face-plants into your Ghost Branch or decides to risk to floating tags. Nab a 4/3 Market Research through SanSan City Grid, Psycho+Trick, or Psycho+Advance+Astroscript Counter.

  • Trick of Light: Cheap to use. Effectively compresses two advancements into one action. Install 3/2 agenda, Advance once, Trick of Light, score. Rinse and repeat as needed.

  • Shipment from SanSan: Softens the blow of all that advancing. Use on ice, ghost branch, agenda. Usually it's best to play them as soon as you get them being that they can't be used in the same turn as Trick.

  • Data Raven: Ever notice how it is always annoying when you're running and the corp rezzes Data Raven? Full rig or not. In the short term the runner jacks out or takes a tag that they have to pay to drop or let you use. In the long term they have to come up with a bypass option if they intend to run that server regularly. I usually wait to install these until I know what servers the runner will be giving preference to. Works well on R&D and in front of SanSan or Ghost Branch.

  • Matrix Analyzer: NBN's trace credits boost its subroutine to Trace 4. Its on-encounter ability lets you compress advancements into the Runner's turn. Advance ice to bolster defense and prep for Trick of Light. Advance Ghost Branch for Trick or diversion.

  • Ice Wall / Shadow: Trick of Light batteries. Advance manually, with Shipment from SanSan, or Matrix Analyzer. Against parasite recursion / ice destruction install 1 of these as an empty remote and never rez to keep your advancements safe.

name: (We Call It) The Walled Garden
description:
The basic premise is to gain lots of money (25 feels optimal), barricade HQ quickly, using Hadrian's or RSVP with Caduceus and then prepare iceless server with Off The Grid and score quickly there. San San can further help with this. So it's basically a Fast Advance, Weyland-flavor.

A lot of deck is just straightforward economy. Hostile Takeover helps from regaining stability from being poor to getting past Hedge Fund threshold and it's a breeze from there.

It's designed to hold Criminal at bay, by preventing Emergency Shutdown and Siphons, but it has some problems with Sneakdoor Beta, especially in early game. Icing R&D isn't that important as by the time decent rig is assembled, you will be at match point.

Draco to further control on-demand-access, Grim to punish Archive or R&D runs. Archer is a bit situational in this deck, as you don't really care about the Runner's rig and you don't want to sacrifice agendas. It works more as a potential threat. You can still influence the rig by playing Power Shutdown, as long as Jackson is in play.

name: Carry A Torch for Her
description:
A questionable attempt at making "a little bit of everything" deck, that's mainly focused on getting full rig in most efficient way and then threat remote servers and/or centrals, if the window opens.

Very event driven (mostly 0's), to accelerate play and save on economy. Proffesional Contacts slows you a bit, but then you need to draw a lot, so it can generate some good money on the go. Test Run/Scavenge is used to assemble the rig plus Scavenge helps switching Femme to different ice. Femme ofc lands on Dinosaurus. The shining star of this deck is Retrieval Run, which 100% time caughts everyone by surprise, especially in the early game. Works very well for pulling Femme and Torch out of heap. Some games even see two Datasuckers, to protect from Power Shutdown and utilize early runs.

It's a bit slow, but as slow as you might think. The biggest issue here is Snowball, which is too weak to fight bigger barriers (costs too much) and installing it on Dinosaurus doesn't make much sense (Grim/Archer).

Public Sympathy designed as a soft counter against Jinteki, but I didn't have the chance to verify it's usefulness.

Stimhack works so well, that I would go further and insert 3 of them. Snowball really needs to go and I really need Parasite in this deck, but that would mean no Criminal tricks. Geez. Choices, choices...

name: Engineering the long game
description: Another idea on a rush/fast advance.Sit back and install ice where needed. Fast advance when you can or sit back and tax the runner with larger ICE. Any remarks are welcome. Thanks

name: Haas-Jinteki
